article.headline: Target permanently raising minimum hourly wage to $15, offering free virtual doctor visits
article.body: Target Corp. TGT, +1.14% announced Wednesday that it will permanently raise its starting U.S. hourly wage to $15, beginning July 5. Target set the goal of raising its minimum wage in 2017, with the last increase to $13 in 2019. The company will also be giving a one-time bonus of $200 to frontline store workers and hourly distribution center workers for their efforts during the coronavirus pandemic. Target will now also offer free virtual doctor visits to all team members through the end of the year, whether or not they are members of the company's healthcare plan. Extended benefits also include a one-time 30-day leave for vulnerable workers, including those who are pregnant or 65 and over; free backup care for children and adults through the end of August; and free mental health counseling. In a separate announcement, Target has also made Juneteenth, the June 19th commemoration of the end of slavery also known as Emancipation Day, a company holiday. Associates working that day will be paid time and a half, workers have the option of taking the day off at full pay, and the corporate headquarters will be closed. Target stock is down 7% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, +0.87% has fallen 3.3% for the period.
